questions.question: A child, upon disturbing a beehive, had several stings. After a few minutes, he developedshock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. What is the pathogenesis of this condition?
Arthus reaction is caused by which of the following process?
questions.explanation: Arthus reaction is characterized by a localized area of tissue necrosis due toimmune-complex-mediated (type III hypersensitivity reaction) vasculitis in the skin.This reaction can be produced experimentally by intracutaneous injection of antigen in apreviously immunised animal that contains circulating antibodies against the antigen. As theantigen diffuses into the vessel wall, it binds with the preformed antibody, and immunecomplexes are formed locally. These complexes precipitate in the vessel walls and cause fibrinoidnecrosis.

questions.question: A 42-year-old female patient presents with ptosis, diplopia, and progressive muscularweakness towards the end of the day. She has improvements in symptoms after administeringedrophonium. The given clinical condition is an example of which of the following?
questions.explanation: The given clinical condition is highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is an example of a type IIhypersensitivity reaction.Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease that is usually associated with autoantibodiesdirected against acetylcholine receptors. In Type II hypersensitivity, antibodies react withantigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause. Theseantibodies destroy cells, trigger inflammation, or interfering with normal functions.

questions.question: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and smoky, cola-coloredurine 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. He is found to have periorbital edema and275mild hypertension. Urine examination shows dysmorphic red cells and red cell casts in theurine with mild proteinuria. Which type of hypersensitivity is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephritic syndrome due to post-streptococcalglomerulonephritis. This is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicitan acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement. The pathogenesis of systemic immune281complex disease can be divided into three phases:• Formation of immune complexes• Deposition of immune complexes•Inflammation and tissue injuryThis results in various manifestations like vasculitis, glomerulonephritis and arthritis.Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions:•⚫ Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis•Systemic lupus erythematosus• Reactive arthritis• Polyarteritis nodosa• Serum sickness• Arthus reaction.•• Farmer's lungHypersensitivity pneumonitis• Type II lepra reaction•Henoch–Schonlein purpuraThe image given below shows the mechanism of type III hypersensitivity reactions.Type III hypersensitivity reactionsB cellAntigen incirculationPlasma cellYoNeutrophilFreeantibodyAntigen-antibodycomplexformationComplementImmunecomplexformationImmunecomplexdepositionOMARROWImmune complexmediatedinflammationand tissue injury-VasculitisPlateletaggregationNeutrophil-lysosomalenzymesreleased

questions.question: A 25-year-old man with a fever and chronic cough is administered 0.1 mL of purified proteinderivative intradermally over the forearm. After a few hours, the injection site appears asfollows. Which of the following does this represent?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario shows a positive tuberculin test. It is a classical example of type IVor delayed or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.282Tuberculin test involves intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also calledtuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. In a previously sensitizedindividual, reddening and induration of the site appear in 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in 24 to 72hours, and thereafter slowly subside.Morphologically, delayed-type hypersensitivity is characterized by the accumulation ofmononuclear cells, mainly CD4+ T cells and macrophages, around venules. The cell-mediated typeof hypersensitivity is caused by inflammation resulting from cytokines produced by CD4+ T cellsand cell killing by CD8+ T cells.

questions.question: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except:
questions.explanation: Anaphylactoid reactions are those reactions that are similar to the anaphylactic reactions but arenot IgE mediated. These reactions are caused by direct degranulation of the mast cells orbasophils, which causes the release of mediators.Unlike the classic anaphylaxis which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoidreaction can occur even on the first exposure. The most common agents that can cause ananaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.In 2014, World Allergy Organisation has introduced two new terms:••Immunologic anaphylaxis - It includes anaphylactic reactions mediated by IgE, IgG (in animals),and immune complex/ complement-mediated reactions.•Non-immunologic anaphylaxis (previously called anaphylactoid reaction) - It includes reactionscaused by agents which cause massive degranulation of mast cells or basophils in the absence ofimmunoglobulin.The image given below shows the sequence of events in type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.Exposure toAllergensType 1 Hypersensitivity ReactionsAllergens(e.g. pollen)Mucosal liningDendritic cellsActivation of TH2cells and IgEclass switchingin B cellsProduction of IgEB cellIgEsecretingB cellsBinding of IgE toFoeRI on mast cellsRepeat exposureto allergenActivation of Mastcell; release ofmediatorsVasoactive amines,lipid mediatorsImmediate hypersensitivityreaction (minutes afterrepeat exposure to allergen)Mast cellMediatorsMARROWCytokinesIgENaiveT cellsTH2collsFOCRILate phase reaction(22-24 hours after repeatexposure toallergen)283

questions.question: Which of the following autoimmune diseases are not mediated by antibodies?
questions.explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis is mediated by T cells, not antibodies.Antibody-mediated diseases:• Autoimmune hemolytic anemia• Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura••Pemphigus vulgaris• Vasculitis caused by ANCA• Goodpasture syndrome•Myasthenia gravis• Acute rheumatic fever• Graves disease• Pernicious anemia• Insulin resistant diabetesT cell-mediated diseases:• Rheumatoid arthritis•Multiple sclerosis• Psoriasis• Type 1 diabetes mellitus••Inflammatory bowel disease•Contact sensitivityNote: In T cell mediated diseases, although the role of T cells have been demonstrated, antibodiesmay also be involved in tissue injury.

questions.question: Which gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity?
questions.explanation: PTPN22 gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.PTPN22, which encodes the protein tyrosine phosphatase, is associated with the followingconditions:• Rheumatoid arthritis• Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)• Type 1 diabetesBecause these disorders have a fairly high prevalence, PTPN22 is said to be the gene that is mostfrequently implicated in autoimmunity.Option A: Mutations in FOXP3 cause a systemic autoimmune disease called IPEX (immunedysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked).284Option C: Polymorphisms in the gene encoding for NOD2 are associated with Crohn's disease.Option D: AIRE mutation is associated with the autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type1 (APS-1).

questions.question: During development, thymic cells recognizing self-antigens are removed to preventautoimmunity. Which gene among the following is involved in the process?
questions.explanation: The above process is called central tolerance and the AIRE (AutoImmune REgulator) protein isnecessary for this process.Immature self-reactive T and B lymphocyte clones recognize self-antigens during their maturationin the central lymphoid organs (thymus for T cells, bone marrow for B cells). They are killed orrendered harmless.The removal of self reacting T lymphocytes in the thymus is called negative selection/ deletion. Forthis process, AIRE protein is needed. Mutations in the AIRE gene results in autoimmunedisorders (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy).B cells undergo a process called receptor editing. When developing B cells encounter an antigen, itformulates a change in the receptor that makes the antigen unrecognizable. Self-reacting B cellscan also undergo apoptosis.

questions.question: Which of the following is responsible for autoimmunity in Epstein-Barr virus infection?
questions.explanation: Autoimmunity in Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection is the result of polyclonal B cell activation.Microbes may induce other abnormalities that promote autoimmune reactions. Some viruses,such as EBV and HIV, cause polyclonal B-cell activation, which may result in the production ofautoantibodies.The role of infections in autoimmunity is exemplified by the following:• Molecular mimicry of antigenic cross-reactivity: The structural similarity of the microbialantigens and self-antigens. Rheumatic heart disease is an example in which streptococcal proteinscross-react with myocardial proteins causing myocarditis.•Upregulation of co-stimulatory molecules by infectious organisms.• Polyclonal B cell activation: Caused by EBV and HIV, resulting in the production ofautoantibodies..Alteration of tissue antigens: Infections may alter tissue self-antigens so that they activate T cellsand lose the property of self-tolerance.

questions.question: Homogeneous or diffuse nuclear staining pattern may reflect antibodies to all the followingexcept:
questions.explanation: Homogeneous or diffuse nuclear staining does not reflect antibodies to RNA. The nucleolarpattern of staining represents antibodies to RNA.285Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) are directed against antibodies to:• DNA• Histones• Nonhistone proteins bound to RNA• Nucleolar antigensThe most widely used method for detecting ANAs is indirect immunofluorescence. The pattern ofnuclear fluorescence suggests the type of antibody present in the patient's serum.

questions.question: What type of cell is the lupus erythematosus cell?
questions.explanation: The lupus erythematosus (LE) cell is a phagocytic neutrophil or macrophage.Nuclei of damaged cells react with ANAs, lose their chromatin pattern, and become homogeneousto produce LE bodies or hematoxylin bodies. Phagocytic neutrophils or macrophages engulf thedenatured nucleus of an injured cell. Demonstration of LE cells in vitro was used in the past forthe diagnosis of SLE.The image below shows a lupus erythematosus (LE) cell.LE cell or hematoxylin bodies

questions.explanation: The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In thiscondition, lymphocytic infiltration in the salivary gland is not seen. However, this finding is seenin Sjogren's syndrome.If cell nuclei are exposed to anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs), they can bind to them. The nuclei ofdamaged cells react with ANAs, lose their chromatin pattern, and become homogeneous. They arecalled lupus erythematosus (LE) bodies or hematoxylin bodies.286An acute necrotizing vasculitis involving capillaries, small arteries, and arterioles with fibrinoidnecrosis is seen in SLE. Central penicilliary arteries in the spleen may show concentric intimaland smooth muscle cell hyperplasia, producing so-called onion-skin lesions.
